# Reserves Management

The global financial markets performed broadly well in 2024. Major economies recorded stable growth, and inflation declined to levels closer to policy targets. Several major central banks gradually reduced policy rates, creating a favorable investment environment. Throughout 2024, the Exchange Fund generated investment income of HK$218.8 billion, with an investment return rate of 5.2%.

# Exchange Fund

Under the Exchange Fund Ordinance, the primary objective of the Exchange Fund is to directly or indirectly influence the exchange rate of the Hong Kong dollar, and may also be used to maintain the stability and soundness of Hong Kong's monetary and financial system, thereby preserving Hong Kong's status as an international financial centre. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) is responsible to the Financial Secretary for the management and investment of the Exchange Fund, based on powers delegated by the Financial Secretary under the relevant provisions.

# Management of the Exchange Fund

# Investment Objectives and Portfolio Structure

The Exchange Fund Advisory Committee (EFAC) has set the following investment objectives for the Exchange Fund:

(i) To preserve capital;
(ii) To ensure that the entire monetary base is fully supported at all times by highly liquid US dollar assets;
(iii) To ensure sufficient liquidity to maintain monetary and financial stability; and
(iv) To seek investment returns as high as possible within the constraints of the above (i) to (iii), in order to safeguard the long-term purchasing power of the Exchange Fund.

These objectives comprehensively reflect the statutory purposes of the Exchange Fund and have been incorporated into the fund's portfolio structure and target asset allocation (Figure 1).

Figure 1 Exchange Fund Portfolio Categories

The Exchange Fund is generally divided into two main portfolios: the Support Portfolio and the Investment Portfolio. The Support Portfolio holds highly liquid US dollar assets that provide full support for the monetary base in accordance with the requirements of the Currency Board system. The Investment Portfolio primarily invests in bond and equity markets of OECD member economies to safeguard the value and long-term purchasing power of the assets.

To better manage risks and enhance medium-term returns, the HKMA has gradually allocated part of the Exchange Fund's assets to more diversified asset classes, including Mainland bonds and equities, private equity (including infrastructure) and real estate. Mainland bonds and equities are held in the Investment Portfolio, while private equity and real estate investments are held in the Long-Term Growth Portfolio (LTGP). The target portfolio mix for the LTGP and other asset categories is developed in line with prudent risk management principles and portfolio diversification strategies.

The Strategic Portfolio was established in 2007 and continues to hold shares in Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited purchased by the Government for strategic purposes. As this portfolio has a unique nature, its performance is not included in the assessment of the Exchange Fund's investment performance.

# Placements with the Exchange Fund

The Exchange Fund occasionally accepts placements from Fiscal Reserves, Government funds, and statutory bodies. The interest rates on these placements are generally linked to the performance of the Investment Portfolio, but for the Future Fund, which is a major example, the interest rates are linked to the returns of both the Investment Portfolio and the Long-Term Growth Portfolio, with the actual rates determined by the asset allocation.

In 2024, the target asset allocation between the Investment Portfolio and the Long-Term Growth Portfolio for the Future Fund was approximately 35:65.

# Investment Process

The Exchange Fund's investment process is based on strategic asset allocation and tactical asset allocation. Strategic asset allocation is reflected in the form of an investment benchmark, which represents the long-term asset allocation that the Exchange Fund can make to achieve its investment objectives. The Exchange Fund uses the strategic allocation as a guide to pursue outperformance relative to the benchmark through tactical asset allocation. Therefore, the actual allocation often deviates from the benchmark allocation (which is the strategic allocation), and this deviation is referred to as "tactical deviation." After consulting the EFAC, the Financial Secretary sets the investment benchmark and tracking error limits, and the HKMA is authorized to determine the tactical asset allocation and establish the permissible range for tactical deviations. Portfolio managers can manage holdings within the permissible range of tactical deviations to profit from short-term market fluctuations.

# Direct Investments

The Exchange Fund Investment Office of the HKMA is responsible for the investment and related risk management functions of the Exchange Fund. This office manages approximately 70% of the Exchange Fund's investments, including the entire Support Portfolio and parts of the Investment Portfolio. This internally managed portfolio includes global fixed-income market investments and executes the Exchange Fund's macro risk management strategies through various derivative instruments.

# External Managers

In addition to managing assets through internal staff, the HKMA employs external managers to manage approximately 30% of the Exchange Fund's assets, including all listed equity portfolios and other special asset classes. The purpose of employing external managers is to utilize the best professional investment talents in the market to invest for the Exchange Fund, generate sustainable returns, and allow the Exchange Fund to benefit from diversified and complementary investment approaches, as well as gain insights and specialized investment knowledge from external managers.

The expenses associated with employing external managers include fund management and custodian fees, transaction costs, withholding taxes, and other taxes. These expenses vary annually due to market factors.

# Risk Management and Monitoring

As the investment environment becomes increasingly complex, robust risk management has become even more important. The HKMA has implemented strict control measures and investment guidelines for investment portfolios managed by both internal and external managers, and has established rigorous risk monitoring and compliance systems. The HKMA has three lines of defense for investment-related activities to implement effective risk management and governance. The HKMA regularly monitors key investment risk categories (including credit, market, liquidity, and operational risks) and establishes risk management procedures to provide a solid framework for strategic planning and diversified investment work.

# Responsible Investing

The HKMA believes that emphasizing responsible investing and the sustainable long-term performance of investments can more effectively achieve the Exchange Fund's investment objectives, and reduce environmental, social, and governance (ESG) related risks associated with investment activities. To actively support responsible investing, the HKMA has integrated ESG factors into the Exchange Fund's investment management process. Its guiding principle is that when ESG investments are comparable to other investment projects in terms of risk-adjusted long-term returns, ESG investments are generally given priority. Details of the HKMA's work on responsible investing can be found in the "Responsible Investment" chapter of the Sustainability Report 2024.

# Performance of the Exchange Fund

# Financial Markets in 2024

The global financial markets performed broadly well in 2024.

Major stock markets saw significant gains in 2024, with the US market showing particular strength in the first three quarters against a backdrop of generally positive economic and inflation fundamentals and the AI boom. However, the fourth quarter saw increased volatility and a pullback from peak levels as concerns over rising inflation and higher bond yields led to a more cautious investor sentiment. In mainland China and Hong Kong, stock markets benefited from a series of policy measures introduced by the central government in the third quarter aimed at stimulating the economy and boosting market confidence. However, both markets softened in the fourth quarter amid continued uncertainty about real economic growth.

Global bond markets experienced significant volatility in 2024. Although major central banks largely confirmed the direction of interest rate cuts, the pace and magnitude of these cuts changed several times during the year. By the fourth quarter, market attention had shifted to U.S. fiscal policies for 2025, leading to a sharp increase in U.S. Treasury yields and pressure on bond prices.

In the money markets, the U.S. dollar strengthened against other major currencies in 2024, particularly in the fourth quarter, driven by strong interest rate trends and the relatively robust performance of the U.S. economy.

Table 1 shows the performance of major currencies, bond markets and equity markets in 2024.

# Exchange Fund Performance

The Exchange Fund achieved investment income of HK$218.8 billion in 2024, comprising:

- Bond investment income of HK$135.9 billion;
- Equity investment income of HK$90.9 billion (of which HK$21.8 billion came from Hong Kong equity investments and HK$69.1 billion from other equity investments);
- A foreign exchange valuation reduction of HK$35.6 billion on non-HKD assets; and
- Other investment income from subsidiaries of the Exchange Fund's invested companies amounting to HK$27.6 billion.

On the other hand, the Strategic Portfolio recorded a valuation gain of HK$2.8 billion.

By the end of 2024, the total assets of the Exchange Fund reached HK$4,081 billion. The total market value of investments in the Long-Term Growth Portfolio amounted to HK$541.2 billion, of which private equity accounted for HK$434.8 billion and real estate for HK$106.4 billion. The total amount committed but not yet drawn down for investment in the Long-Term Growth Portfolio was HK$288.6 billion.

The Exchange Fund (excluding the Strategic Portfolio) achieved an investment return rate of 5.2% in 2024, with the Investment Portfolio returning 7.2% and the Support Portfolio returning 4.1%. The Long-Term Growth Portfolio has delivered an annualized internal rate of return of 11.2% since its inception in 2009.

Figure 1 shows the annual return rates of the Exchange Fund from 1994 to 2024. Table 2 displays the investment return rates of the Exchange Fund in 2024 and average investment return rates for different periods. The Exchange Fund's average return rate was 2.0% for 2022-2024, 3.1% for 2020-2024, 3.1% for 2015-2024, and 4.5% since 1994. Table 3 lists the currency composition of the Exchange Fund's assets as of December 31, 2024. Details are available in the audited 2024 financial statements of the Exchange Fund on pages 203 to 309.

# 機構職能

機構職能部門支持金管局的運作，保持高透明度與問責性，並發揮卓越的效率及專業水準。為促進公眾對金管局的政策及工作的了解，金管局透過傳統及社交媒體、金管局網站、金管局資訊中心及其他渠道積極與整體社會及市場參與者保持聯繫。

對內方面，金管局致力建立一支靈活應變及專業的工作團隊，同時遵守嚴格的財政紀律及提升數碼能力，應對變化及確保有效執行各項政策及措施。

# 保持透明度

# 傳媒關係及社交媒體應用

金管局與傳媒保持緊密聯繫，以提高透明度及增進公眾對其政策及運作的了解。金管局在2024年共舉辦或參與207次活動，包括14次新聞發布會、四次傳媒簡報會、14次即場訪問及175次其他公開活動。為增進社會對金管局主要職能的認識，金管局為本地、內地及境外的媒體舉辦新聞發布會及傳媒簡報會，涵蓋代幣化、防騙措施及支援中小企措施等主題。年內金管局亦安排25次媒體訪談、發布約600份雙語新聞稿，並處理大量傳媒日常查詢。

總裁余偉文先生於「香港金融科技周2024」接受媒體即場訪問

副總裁李達志先生於「戶口互聯」用例展示日致歡迎辭

傳媒代表積極參與金管局在2024年舉辦的活動，尤其是第三屆「國際金融領袖投資峰會」。峰會為期三日，獲得本地、內地及國際媒體逾萬篇新聞報道。

總裁余偉文先生於「國際金融領袖投資峰會2024」接受媒體直播訪問

副總裁阮國恒先生就成立「中小企融資專責小組」主持傳媒簡報會

副總裁陳維民先生於「2024財資市場高峰會」上致開幕辭

為更有效聯繫公眾，金管局共營運六個社交媒體專頁（包括Facebook、Instagram、LinkedIn、WeChat、X（前稱Twitter）及YouTube），獲超過200,000名用戶關注。金管局製作富創意的社交媒體內容，提高公眾對一系列議題及舉措的認識，例如防騙、金融科技、綠色和可持續金融、支援中小企及金管局舉辦的大型盛事等。金管局亦在其社交媒體專頁直播「國際金融領袖投資峰會」，促進公眾及業界參與。

在社交媒體發布創意內容，有助增加公眾對金管局舉措及各類議題的認識

# 公眾查詢

金管局的公眾查詢服務為市民提供有效渠道，以增進其對金管局主要職能及運作的認識。

在2024年公眾查詢服務共處理9,594宗查詢（圖1），全部都在金管局服務承諾時限內回覆（表1）。這些查詢中約有一半涉及銀行消費者事宜、金融基建與債券市場發展、銀行業政策及規例，以及紙幣與硬幣（圖2）。常見的查詢包括硬幣收集計劃、銀行產品及服務、零售債券發行計劃、銀行業相關指引與通告，以及「轉數快」。

圖 1 公眾查詢總數

圖 2 按性質列出2024年接獲的查詢

# 刊物

年內金管局出版《二零二三年年報》及《二零二三年可持續發展報告》。《二零二三年可持續發展報告》在香港會計師公會「最佳企業管治及ESG大獎2024」的「公眾/非牟利機構（大型）」類別中獲得評判嘉許獎。此外，《二零二三年年報》在香港管理專業協會2024年度最佳年報評選中獲得「非牟利及慈善機構」類銅獎。

在2024年，金管局定期更新《金融數據月報》1資料，並出版：

- 兩期《貨幣與金融穩定情況半年度報告》
- 四期《季報》；及
- 14篇《匯思》文章。

# 機構網站

機構網站(www.hkma.gov.hk)提供73,000多頁英文版及繁簡字體中文版資料，方便公眾查閱金管局的最新資訊。網站亦載有根據《銀行業條例》第20條備存的「認可機構及本地代表辦事處紀錄冊」及「認可機構證券業務員工紀錄冊」，以及根據《支付系統及儲值支付工具條例》備存的「儲值支付工具持牌人紀錄冊」。

金管局自2018年起透過開放應用程式介面（開放API），分階段發放在其網站所載的金融數據及重要資訊。截至2024年底，我們按照原定計劃在網站推出合共177組開放API。有關金管局開放API的更詳盡資料，請瀏覽金管局開放API門戶網站(https://apidocs.hkma.gov.hk)。

# 資訊中心

金管局資訊中心設於國際金融中心2期55樓，分為展覽館及圖書館兩部分，旨在向公眾介紹金管局的工作，並提高公眾對貨幣與銀行業事宜的認識。展覽館以互動方式簡介金管局的工作，以及香港貨幣與銀行業的發展；另備資料與展品，供研究香港貨幣、銀行業與金融事務。

年內資訊中心接待超過68,000名訪客，較2023年增加約120%。資訊中心亦為學校及其他團體提供570多次導賞服務。

毗鄰展覽館的圖書館收藏超過26,000冊書籍、期刊及其他刊物，涵蓋香港貨幣、銀行業、金融和中央銀行事務等課題。圖書館亦備存《銀行業條例》第20條規定的「認可機構及本地代表辦事處紀錄冊」及「認可機構證券業務員工紀錄冊」，供公眾查閱。

幼稚園生參加資訊中心導賞，認識有關香港鈔票的設計

資訊中心人員向訪客介紹以香港硬幣砌出維港景色的馬賽克作品

# 社區聯繫及公眾教育

為增進市民對金管局工作的認識，金管局自1998年起推出公眾教育講座，至今錄得參加者人數超過68,000名。於2024年，我們舉行網上講座，吸引800多名來自41間中學的師生參加。講座內容涵蓋金管局工作簡介、聯繫匯率制度、香港鈔票、防騙、存款保障計劃、綠色金融及銀行業發展機遇。

我們使用不同渠道聯繫及教育公眾，提醒他們如何做個精明及負責任的金融服務消費者。2024年的活動合共吸引超過67,000名市民參與。

為配合數碼支付及綠色生活的趨勢，我們透過社交媒體及電台宣傳，鼓勵市民於農曆新年期間派發電子利是，亦可考慮以「迎新鈔」派發實體利是。

製作動畫短片鼓勵派發電子利是

# 防騙歌曲 — 《Link咪亂撳》

為進一步加強防騙工作，我們推出由歌手尹光先生與金管局副總裁阮國恒先生合唱的防騙歌曲，提醒市民「假Link咪當真，唔好俾人昆」，以及要妥善保管敏感的個人資料與信用卡資料。跨媒體宣傳活動的成效得到肯定，取得國際推廣殊榮。

副總裁阮國恒先生（右）參與演繹防騙歌曲

跨媒體宣傳活動加強公眾防騙意識

# 《跨境理財新機遇》電視短片系列

金管局與一間本地電視台聯合製作《跨境理財新機遇》電視短片系列，協助市民進一步了解「粵港澳大灣區跨境理財通」（「跨境理財通」）為零售投資者在跨境投資上帶來的機遇及便利。這短片系列藉五部膾炙人口的港產電影的「經典場面」，解說「跨境理財通」的框架、投資者的資格要求、「北向通」與「南向通」提供的產品、風險管理，以及跨境投資應注意的事項，並透過電視、數碼及社交媒體平台進行推廣。

短片以風趣幽默的方式介紹「跨境理財通」

# 全港理財爭霸戰

為提高中學生的理財知識，金管局與多個相關機構合作舉辦「全港理財爭霸戰」。該活動在2024年踏入十周年，主題為「未來金融人才」，旨在讓中學生及早認識創新、金融科技、人工智能等發展及未來動向，以及推動學生秉持可持續發展與環境、社會及管治原則。

爭霸戰第一部分是網上問答比賽，測試參賽學生的理財知識及對熱門金融課題的認識。於2024年，來自290所中學共32,000人次參與網上問答比賽，創下歷年新高。在2015年至2024年間，來自440所中學的學生參與爭霸戰的網上問答比賽環節共約125,000次。爭霸戰的第二部分「少年金融人才計劃」以師友形式進行，由不同範疇的資深從業員擔任導師，培訓學生準備參與「設計思維挑戰賽」。在2024年，這部分的爭霸戰更特別增設「大灣區邀請賽」，以促進粵港澳三地學生互動交流。

副總裁陳維民先生在爭霸戰總決賽致歡迎辭，並為總決賽參賽者打氣

參與「少年金融人才計劃」的學生與導師會面

# 桌上教育遊戲

金管局在2023年推出其首個理財教育桌上遊戲《$mart理財321》，並於2024年繼續推廣，讓更多人認識這副原創桌遊，並加強其作為教育工具的用途，讓小學生在模擬情景下認識不同的支付方法、基本理財概念、金融科技及網絡安全。

在社區層面，我們於「香港書展2024」設置攤位，並在聖誕節及農曆新年期間於社區舉辧工作坊，以及在金管局辦事處舉辦親子工作坊，進一步推廣金融及理財概念。此外，我們亦安排到校活動讓小學生試玩，並舉辦培訓工作坊，鼓勵中學教師在新設初中科目「公民、經濟與社會」的理財教育單元中使用桌遊作為教材之一。桌遊得到教育局肯定為出色的教學工具之一，並用作其舉辦的「理財教育學校獎勵計劃」（2023/24）優勝學校的獎品。金管局在2024年合共舉辧約40場桌遊工作坊，獲得超過3,600名學生、家長、教師及社工參與。

在開發《$mart理財321》桌遊的經驗基礎上，金管局推出策略桌遊《企業綠化大變身》，於「香港書展2024」的攤位作為紀念品送出。這是全港首副向學生傳遞綠色金融知識的桌遊。

此外，我們繼續支持投資者及理財教育委員會的工作，提升香港市民的金融知識及理財能力，並會研究與不同持份者進一步合作，提高社區參與工作的成效。

透過桌遊活動向教師、學童及家長推廣理財教育

# 財務披露

為維持高透明度，金管局採納適用於中央銀行運作的國際財務披露標準，包括香港財務報告準則及國際貨幣基金組織的數據公布特殊標準。財務處在獨立審計師及其他會計專業人員協助下，按照香港財務報告準則編製外匯基金財務報表。此外，金管局在《年報》詳細披露及深入分析預算及支出資料（請參閱第193至194頁「預算編製及財務管控」一節）。

en:
# Corporate Functions

The corporate functions departments support the operations of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA), maintaining high transparency and accountability, and demonstrating excellent efficiency and professionalism. To promote public understanding of the HKMA's policies and work, the HKMA actively maintains communication with the broader society and market participants through traditional and social media, the HKMA website, the HKMA Information Centre, and other channels.

Internally, the HKMA is committed to building a flexible and professional workforce, while adhering to strict financial discipline and enhancing digital capabilities to respond to changes and ensure effective implementation of policies and measures.

# Maintaining Transparency

# Media Relations and Social Media Usage

The HKMA maintains close contact with the mass media to enhance transparency and improve public understanding of its policies and operations. In 2024, the HKMA held or participated in 207 activities, including 14 press conferences, four media briefings, 14 stand-up interviews, and 175 other public events. To increase public awareness of the HKMA's core functions, the HKMA organized press conferences and media briefings for local, mainland China, and overseas media, covering topics such as tokenisation, anti-scam initiatives, and support measures for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). Throughout the year, the HKMA arranged 25 media interviews, issued approximately 600 bilingual press releases, and handled numerous routine media inquiries.

Mr. Eddie Yue, Chief Executive of the HKMA, was interviewed by the media during the "Hong Kong FinTech Week 2024"

Mr. David Li, Deputy Chief Executive of the HKMA, delivered a welcome speech at the "Interbank Linkage" use case demonstration day

Media representatives actively participated in the HKMA's events in 2024, particularly the third edition of the "Global Financial Leaders' Investment Summit". The three-day summit received over 10,000 news reports from local, mainland China, and international media.

Mr. Eddie Yue, Chief Executive of the HKMA, was interviewed live by the media at the "Global Financial Leaders' Investment Summit 2024"

Mr. Ronald Mak, Deputy Chief Executive of the HKMA, hosted a media briefing on the establishment of the "SME Lending Task Force"

Mr. Victor Chan, Deputy Chief Executive of the HKMA, delivered opening remarks at the "2024 Treasury Markets Summit"

To better connect with the public, the HKMA operates six social media pages (including Facebook, Instagram, LinkedIn, WeChat, X (formerly Twitter), and YouTube), with over 200,000 followers. The HKMA produces creative social media content to raise public awareness of various issues and initiatives, such as fraud prevention, fintech, green and sustainable finance, SME support, and major events organised by the HKMA. The HKMA also live-streamed the "Global Financial Leaders' Investment Summit" on its social media pages to encourage public and industry participation.

Creative content on social media helps increase public awareness of the HKMA's initiatives and various issues

# Public Enquiries

The HKMA's Public Enquiry Service provides an effective channel for members of the public to gain a better understanding of the HKMA's key functions and operations.

In 2024, the Public Enquiry Service processed 9,594 enquiries (Figure 1), all of which were responded to within the HKMA's service commitment timeframe (Table 1). Approximately half of these enquiries related to consumer banking matters, financial infrastructure and bond market developments, banking policies and regulations, and notes and coins (Figure 2). Common enquiries included the Coin Collection Programme, bank products and services, the Retail Bond Issuance Programme, banking-related guidelines and notices, and "Faster Payment System".

Figure 1 Total number of public enquires

Figure 2 Breakdown of 2024 public enquires by nature

# Publications

During the year, the HKMA published the "Annual Report 2023" and the "Sustainability Report 2023". The "Sustainability Report 2023" received commendation from the judges in the "Public / Non-Profit Organisations (Large)" category of the "Best Corporate Governance and ESG Awards 2024" by the Hong Kong Institute of Certified Public Accountants (HKICPA). Additionally, the "Annual Report 2023" won the bronze award in the "Non-Profit and Charitable Organisations" category in the 2024 Best Annual Report Awards by the Hong Kong Management Association.

In 2024, the HKMA regularly updated the "Monthly Statistical Bulletin", and published:

- Two editions of the "Half-Yearly Report on Monetary and Financial Stability"
- Four editions of the "Quarterly Review"; and
- 14 articles titled "Insights".

# Institutional Website

The institutional website (www.hkma.gov.hk) provides more than 73,000 pages of English and simplified/traditional Chinese versions of information, facilitating public access to the latest information from the HKMA. The website also contains records of "Register of Authorised Institutions and Local Representative Offices" and "Register of Securities Staff of Authorised Institutions" under Section 20 of the Banking Ordinance, as well as the "Register of Stored Value Facility Licensees" under the Payment Systems and Stored Value Facilities Ordinance.

Since 2018, the HKMA has been gradually releasing financial data and important information available on its website through open application programming interfaces (Open APIs). As of the end of 2024, we have launched a total of 177 sets of Open APIs. For more detailed information about the HKMA's Open APIs, please visit the HKMA Open API portal (https://apidocs.hkma.gov.hk).

# Information Centre

The HKMA Information Centre, located on the 55th floor of International Finance Centre Phase II, consists of an exhibition hall and a library, aiming to introduce the HKMA's work to the public and enhance public awareness of monetary and banking affairs. The exhibition hall introduces the HKMA's work and the development of Hong Kong's monetary and banking sectors through interactive displays, and provides materials and exhibits for research on Hong Kong's currency, banking, and financial affairs.

Throughout the year, the Information Centre welcomed over 68,000 visitors, representing an increase of approximately 120% compared to 2023. The Information Centre also provided 570+ guided tours for schools and other groups.

Adjacent to the exhibition hall, the library houses over 26,000 books, journals, and publications covering topics relating to Hong Kong's currency, banking, finance, and central banking affairs. The library also keeps the "Register of Authorised Institutions and Local Representative Offices" and "Register of Securities Staff of Authorised Institutions" required under Section 20 of the Banking Ordinance, as well as the "Register of Stored Value Facility Licensees" required under the Payment Systems and Stored Value Facilities Ordinance, for public reference.

Kindergarten students participate in a tour of the Information Centre to learn about the design of Hong Kong banknotes

Information Centre staff introduce visitors to a mosaic artwork made from Hong Kong coins depicting the Victoria Harbour

# Community Engagement and Public Education

To enhance public awareness of the HKMA's work, the HKMA has been offering public education lectures since 1998, with over 68,000 participants to date. In 2024, we held online lectures that attracted more than 800 participants from 41 secondary schools. Topics covered included an introduction to the HKMA's work, the Linked Exchange Rate System, Hong Kong banknotes, fraud prevention, the Deposit Protection Scheme, green financing, and career opportunities in the banking industry.

We use various channels to engage and educate the public on how to become informed and responsible consumers of financial services. Activities in 2024 attracted over 67,000 members of the public.

To align with the trends of digital payments and green living, we promoted the use of electronic lai see (red envelopes) through social media and radio stations during the Lunar New Year period, and encouraged people to consider using "new-year banknotes" for physical red envelopes.

Animated short film encouraging the distribution of electronic lai see

# Anti-Fraud Song - "Link Mee Loon Koon"

To further strengthen our anti-fraud efforts, we launched an anti-fraud song featuring Mr. Jackson Wan Kwong and Mr. Ronald Mak, Deputy Chief Executive of the HKMA, reminding the public "Don't take fake links seriously, don't let others exploit your personal information." The cross-media promotional campaign received recognition and achieved international acclaim.

Mr. Ronald Mak (right) participated in the performance of the anti-fraud song

Cross-media promotional campaign enhances public awareness of fraud prevention

# "Cross-border Wealth Management Opportunities" TV Series

The HKMA collaborated with a local television station to produce the "Cross-border Wealth Management Opportunities" TV series, helping residents understand the opportunities and conveniences offered by the "Cross-border Wealth Management Connect" (WMC) for retail investors in cross-border investments. This series uses five popular Hong Kong films' "classic scenes" to explain the framework of the WMC, investor eligibility requirements, products available through the Northbound and Southbound Schemes, risk management, and considerations for cross-border investments, and promotes it through television, digital, and social media platforms.

The series presents the WMC in a humorous and engaging way

# Hong Kong Financial Literacy Championship

To enhance secondary school students' financial knowledge, the HKMA partnered with multiple relevant organisations to hold the "Hong Kong Financial Literacy Championship". This event reached its tenth anniversary in 2024, with the theme "Next-gen Finance", aiming to help secondary school students understand emerging trends in innovation, fintech, artificial intelligence, and future directions, and to promote students' adherence to environmental, social, and governance (ESG) principles.

The first part of the championship is an online quiz competition testing participants' financial knowledge and understanding of current financial topics. In 2024, 32,000 participants from 290 secondary schools took part in the online quiz, setting a new record. Between 2015 and 2024, approximately 125,000 participants from 440 secondary schools took part in the online quiz component of the championship.

The second part of the championship, the "Young Financial Talent Runway", adopts a mentorship approach, where professionals from different fields serve as mentors to guide students in preparing for the "Design Thinking Challenge". In 2024, this part of the championship introduced the "GBA Invitation Match" to promote interaction and exchanges among students from the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area (GBA).

Mr. Victor Chan, Deputy Chief Executive of the HKMA, delivered a welcoming address at the championship final and encouraged the participants.

Students participating in the "Young Financial Talent Runway" meet with their mentors

# Board Game Educational Activities

The HKMA launched its first financial education board game, "$mart Money Management 321," in 2023, and continued promoting it in 2024 to raise awareness of this original board game and enhance its effectiveness as an educational tool, allowing primary school students to learn about different payment methods, basic financial concepts, fintech, and cybersecurity in simulated scenarios.

At the community level, we set up a booth at the "Hong Kong Book Fair 2024" and conducted workshops during the Christmas and Lunar New Year periods in communities, as well as family workshops at HKMA offices, further promoting financial and financial literacy concepts. Additionally, we arranged school visits for primary school students to try out the game and held training workshops to encourage secondary school teachers to use the board game as a teaching resource in the "Citizenship, Economics and Society" subject. The board game was recognized by the Education Bureau as one of the outstanding teaching tools and was awarded to winning schools in the "Financial Education School Award Scheme" (2023/24). The HKMA held approximately 40 board game workshops in 2024, with over 3,600 students, parents, teachers, and social workers participating.

Building on the experience of developing the "$mart Money Management 321" board game, the HKMA launched the strategy board game "$mart Green Transformation", which was given away as a souvenir at the "Hong Kong Book Fair 2024" booth. This is the first board game in Hong Kong aimed at conveying green finance knowledge to students.

Additionally, we continue to support the work of the Investor and Financial Education Council to enhance the financial knowledge and investment capabilities of Hong Kong residents, and will explore further collaboration with various stakeholders to improve the effectiveness of community engagement initiatives.

Through board game activities, we promote financial education to teachers, students, and parents

# Financial Disclosure

To maintain high transparency, the HKMA adopts internationally applicable financial disclosure standards for central bank operations, including Hong Kong Financial Reporting Standards and the IMF's Special Data Dissemination Standard. The Finance Division prepares the Exchange Fund financial statements in accordance with Hong Kong Financial Reporting Standards, with assistance from independent auditors and other accounting professionals. Additionally, the HKMA discloses and thoroughly analyses budget and expenditure information in the Annual Report (please refer to the section "Budget Preparation and Financial Control" on pages 193 to 194).

zh:
# 外匯基金

- 審計署署長報告
- 外匯基金財務報表

# 審計署署長報告

# 香港特別行政區政府審璚計毐署

# 獨立審計師報告致財政司司長

# 意見

茲證明我已審計列載於第209至309頁外匯基金及其附屬公司（「集團」）的財務報表，該等財務報表包括外匯基金及集團於2024年12月31日的資產負債表與截至該日止年度的收支帳目、全面收益表、權益變動表和現金流量表，以及財務報表的附註，包括重大會計政策資料。

我認為，該等財務報表已按照香港會計師公會頒布的《香港財務報告會計準則》真實而中肯地反映外匯基金及集團於2024年12月31日的財務狀況及截至該日止年度的財務表現和現金流量，並已按照行政長官在《外匯基金條例》（第66章）第7條下所發出的指示妥為擬備。

# 意見的基礎

我已按照行政長官在《外匯基金條例》第7條下所發出的指示及審計署的審計準則進行審計。我根據該等準則而須承擔的責任，詳載於本報告「審計師就財務報表審計而須承擔的責任」部分。根據該等準則，我獨立於集團，並已按該等準則履行其他道德責任。我相信，我所獲得的審計憑證是充足和適當地為我的審計意見提供基礎。

# 關鍵審計事項

關鍵審計事項是根據我的專業判斷，對截至2024年12月31日止年度財務報表的審計最為重要的事項。我對整體財務報表進行審計及形成意見時處理了這些事項，而我不會對這些事項提供單獨的意見。

# 按公平值列帳的金融資產及金融負債的估值

請參閱財務報表附註2.5、2.6及37.1。

於2024年12月31日，集團按公平值列帳的金融資產共 39,151.17 億港元，金融負債共 13,862.99 億港元。

86%的該等金融資產及所有該等金融負債的公平值為相同資產或負債於活躍市場的報價（第1級參數），或是以估值方法估計，而所用的參數是以可觀察市場數據為基礎（第2級參數）。

其餘14%的該等金融資產的公平值，是以估值方法估計，而所用的參數並非以可觀察市場數據為基礎（第3級參數）。有關金融資產共5,522.51億港元，主要包括非上市投資基金。

鑑於所涉數額龐大及涉及估計，按公平值列帳的金 融資產及金融負債的估值屬關鍵審計事項。

就按公平值列帳的金融資產及金融負債的估值，審計程序包括：

- 了解不同類別金融資產及金融負債的估值程序，包括相關監控措施；

- 評價及測試監控措施，包括電腦系統的相關應用程式監控措施；

- 就金融資產及金融負債的估值、存在、權利與責任及完整性取得函證；

- 若使用市場報價，根據獨立來源核實價格；

- 若所用估值方法的參數是以可觀察市場數據為基礎，評價估值方法是否適合及有關假設是否合理，以及根據獨立來源核實參數；及

- 若所用估值方法的參數並非以可觀察市場數據為基礎，評價估值方法是否適合，以及有關假設與參數是否合理。

# 按公平值列帳的投資物業的估值

請參閱財務報表附註2.11、17及18。

集團的投資物業按公平值列帳，於2024年12月31日共值211.32億港元。集團亦於聯營公司及合營公司擁有權益，該等公司主要業務為持有海外投資物業。不論是由集團直接持有或由聯營公司或合營公司持有，該等投資物業的公平值均主要根據獨立專業估值師的估值釐定。該等估值涉及重大判斷及估計，包括所用的估值方法及假設。

就按公平值列帳的投資物業的估值，審計程序包括：

- 獲取及審視由集團直接持有或由聯營公司或合營公司持有的投資物業的估值報告，並核實公平值是根據有關估值報告所列的估值釐定；

- 評估估值師的獨立性及資歷；及

- 評價估值方法是否適合，以及有關假設與參數是否合理。

# 其他資料

金融管理專員須對其他資料負責。其他資料包括金融管理局2024年年報內的所有資料，但不包括財務報表及我的審計師報告。

我對財務報表的意見並不涵蓋其他資料，我亦不對其他資料發表任何形式的鑒證結論。

就財務報表審計而言，我有責任閱讀其他資料，從而考慮其他資料是否與財務報表或我在審計過程中得悉的情況有重大矛盾，或者似乎存有重大錯誤陳述。基於我已執行的工作，如果我認為其他資料存有重大錯誤陳述，我需要報告該事實。在這方面，我沒有任何報告。

# 金融管理專員及外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會就財務報表而須承擔的責任

金融管理專員須負責按照香港會計師公會頒布的《香港財務報告會計準則》及行政長官在《外匯基金條例》第7條下所發出的指示擬備真實而中肯的財務報表，及落實其認為必要的內部控制， 使財務報表不存有因欺詐或錯誤而導致的重大錯誤陳述。

在擬備財務報表時，金融管理專員須負責評估集團持續經營的能力，以及在適用情況下披露與持續經營有關的事項，並以持續經營作為會計基礎。

外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會負責監督集團的財務報告過程。

# 審計師就財務報表審計而須承擔的責任

我的目標是就整體財務報表是否不存有任何因欺詐或錯誤而導致的重大錯誤陳述取得合理保證，並發出包括我意見的審計師報告。合理保證是高水平的保證，但不能確保按審計署審計準則進行的審計定能發現所存有的任何重大錯誤陳述。錯誤陳述可以由欺詐或錯誤引起，如果合理預期它們個別或滙總起來可能影響財務報表使用者所作出的經濟決定，則會被視作重大錯誤陳述。

在根據審計署審計準則進行審計的過程中，我會運用專業判斷並秉持專業懷疑態度。我亦會：

- 識別和評估因欺詐或錯誤而導致財務報表存有重大錯誤陳述的風險；設計及執行審計程序以應對這些風險；以及取得充足和適當的審計憑證，作為我意見的基礎。由於欺詐可能涉及串謀、偽造、蓄意遺漏、虛假陳述，或凌駕內部控制的情況，因此未能發現因欺詐而導致重大錯誤陳述的風險，較未能發現因錯誤而導致者為高；

- 了解與審計相關的內部控制，以設計適當的審計程序。然而，此舉並非旨在對集團內部控制的有效性發表意見；

- 評價金融管理專員所採用的會計政策是否恰當，以及其作出的會計估計和相關資料披露是否合理；

- 判定金融管理專員以持續經營作為會計基礎的做法是否恰當，並根據所得的審計憑證，判定是否存在與事件或情況有關，而且可能對集團持續經營的能力構成重大疑慮的重大不確定性。如果我認為存在重大不確定性，則有必要在審計師報告中請使用者留意財務報表中的相關資料披露。假若所披露的相關資料不足，我便須發出非無保留意見的審計師報告。我的結論是基於截至審計師報告日止所取得的審計憑證。然而，未來事件或情況可能導致集團不能繼續持續經營；

- 評價財務報表的整體列報方式、結構和內容，包括披露資料，以及財務報表是否中肯反映交易和事項；及

-計劃並執行集團審計，以就集團中實體或業務單位的財務資料獲取充足和適當的審計憑證，作為對財務報表形成意見的基礎。我負責指導、監督和審視為進行集團審計而履行的審計工作。我對我的審計意見承擔全部責任。

我會與外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會溝通計劃的審計範圍和時間以及重大審計發現等事項，包括我在審計期間識別出內部控制的任何重大缺陷。

我亦會向外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會提交聲明，說明我已符合有關獨立性的相關道德要求，並與他們溝通所有被合理認為可能會影響我獨立性的關係和其他事項，以及在適用的情況下，相關的防範措施。

從與外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會溝通的事項中，我會決定哪些事項對本期財務報表的審計最為重要，因而構成關鍵審計事項。我會在審計師報告中描述這些事項，除非法律法規不允許對某件事項作出公開披露，或在極端罕見的情況下，因為有合理預期在我報告中溝通某事項而造成的負面後果將會超過其產生的公眾利益而我決定不應在報告中溝通該事項。

# 外匯基金 – 財務報表附註

（除特別註明外，所有金額均以港幣百萬元位列示。）

# 1 主要業務

金融管理專員根據財政司司長以外匯基金（基金）管理人身分授予的權力，按照《外匯基金條例》（第66章）的條文管理基金。基金的主要業務為捍衛港元匯率及維持香港貨幣及金融體系的穩定健全。

基金的資產分作四個不同的組合來管理：支持組合、投資組合、長期增長組合及策略性資產組合。根據香港的貨幣發行局制度，支持組合的資產與貨幣基礎完全相配。投資組合主要投資於經濟合作與發展組織成員國的債券及股票市場。長期增長組合持有私募股權及房地產投資。策略性資產組合持有香港特別行政區（香港特區）政府為策略目的而購入，並列入基金的帳目內的香港交易及結算所有限公司的股票。經營分部資料載於附註31。

# Exchange Fund

- Director of Audit's Report
- Exchange Fund Financial Statements

# Director of Audit's Report

# Office of the Director of Audit, The Government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region

# Independent Auditor's Report to the Financial Secretary

# Opinion

I have audited the financial statements of the Exchange Fund and its subsidiaries ("the Group") set out on pages 209 to 309. These financial statements include the balance sheets of the Exchange Fund and the Group as at 31 December 2024, and the income and expenditure accounts, statements of comprehensive income, statements of changes in equity, and statements of cash flows for the year ended on that date, together with the notes to the financial statements, including information on significant accounting policies.

In my opinion, these financial statements present fairly the financial position of the Exchange Fund and the Group as at 31 December 2024, and their financial performance and cash flows for the year ended on that date, in accordance with the Hong Kong Financial Reporting Standards issued by the Hong Kong Institute of Certified Public Accountants, and have been prepared in accordance with the instructions issued by the Chief Executive under section 7 of the Exchange Fund Ordinance (Cap. 66).

# Basis of Opinion

I have conducted the audit in accordance with the instructions issued by the Chief Executive under section 7 of the Exchange Fund Ordinance and the Audit Commission's auditing standards. My responsibilities relating to the audit of the financial statements are detailed in the section entitled "Responsibilities of the Auditor in Relation to the Audit of the Financial Statements" in this report. Under those standards, I am independent of the Group and have fulfilled other ethical responsibilities in accordance with the relevant professional standards.

I believe that the audit evidence obtained is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for my audit opinion.

# Key Audit Matters

Key audit matters are those identified by my professional judgment that are most significant to the audit of the financial statements for the year ended 31 December 2024. I have addressed these matters in the overall audit and formed an opinion on the financial statements as a whole, but I do not express a separate opinion on these matters.

# Valuation of Financial Assets and Financial Liabilities Measured at Fair Value

See Notes 2.5, 2.6 and 37.1 to the financial statements.

As at 31 December 2024, the Group had financial assets measured at fair value amounting to HK$391,511.7 billion and financial liabilities measured at fair value amounting to HK$138,629.9 billion.

86% of these financial assets and all of these financial liabilities were valued using quoted prices in active markets (Level 1 inputs), or valuation techniques based on observable market data (Level 2 inputs). 

The remaining 14% of these financial assets were valued using valuation techniques where the inputs were not based on observable market data (Level 3 inputs). These financial assets amounted to HK$55,225.1 billion, primarily consisting of unlisted investment funds.

Given the material amounts involved and the nature of the estimates, the valuation of financial assets and financial liabilities measured at fair value constitutes a key audit matter.

Audit procedures related to the valuation of financial assets and financial liabilities measured at fair value included:

- Understanding the valuation processes for different categories of financial assets and financial liabilities, including related control measures;
- Evaluating and testing the control measures, including application controls over computer systems;
- Obtaining confirmations regarding the valuation, existence, rights and obligations, and completeness of financial assets and financial liabilities;
- Verifying prices from independent sources if quoted prices were used;
- Assessing whether the valuation techniques were appropriate and whether the assumptions underlying the valuations were reasonable, and verifying the inputs from independent sources if the inputs were based on observable market data; and
- Assessing whether the valuation techniques were appropriate, and whether the assumptions and inputs were reasonable, if the inputs were not based on observable market data.

# Valuation of Investment Properties Measured at Fair Value

See Notes 2.11, 17 and 18 to the financial statements.

The Group's investment properties are measured at fair value and amounted to HK$21,132 billion as at 31 December 2024. The Group also holds interests in associate and joint ventures, which mainly engage in holding overseas investment properties. Whether held directly by the Group or through associates or joint ventures, the fair values of these investment properties are primarily determined by independent professional valuers' valuations. These valuations involve significant judgments and estimates, including the valuation methods and assumptions used.

Audit procedures related to the valuation of investment properties measured at fair value included:

- Obtaining and reviewing the valuation reports for investment properties held directly by the Group or through associates or joint ventures, and verifying that the fair values were determined in accordance with the valuations set out in those reports;
- Assessing the independence and qualifications of the valuers;
- And evaluating whether the valuation methods were appropriate, and whether the assumptions and inputs were reasonable.

# Other Information

The Monetary Authority is responsible for other information. Other information includes all information contained in the Annual Report of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority for 2024, but does not include the financial statements or my auditor's report.

My opinion on the financial statements does not cover other information, and I do not express any form of assurance conclusion on other information.

In relation to the audit of the financial statements, I have a responsibility to read other information in order to consider whether other information is materially inconsistent with the financial statements or with information known during the audit, or appears to contain material misstatements. Based on the work I have performed, if I conclude that other information contains material misstatements, I would need to report this fact. In this regard, I have no such reports.

# Responsibilities of the Monetary Authority and the Audit Sub-Committee of the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee in Respect of the Financial Statements

The Monetary Authority is responsible for preparing true and fair financial statements in accordance with the Hong Kong Financial Reporting Standards issued by the Hong Kong Institute of Certified Public Accountants and the instructions issued by the Chief Executive under section 7 of the Exchange Fund Ordinance, and implementing internal controls that it considers necessary to prevent material misstatements arising from fraud or error.

In preparing the financial statements, the Monetary Authority is responsible for assessing the Group's ability to continue as a going concern, and disclosing matters relating to going concern where applicable, and using going concern as the basis of accounting.

The Audit Sub-Committee of the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee is responsible for overseeing the Group's financial reporting process.

# Responsibilities of the Auditor in Relation to the Audit of the Financial Statements

My objective is to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the overall financial statements are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error, and to issue an auditor's report that includes my opinion. Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance, but it cannot guarantee that the audit conducted in accordance with the Audit Commission's auditing standards will detect any material misstatement. A material misstatement may arise from fraud or error, and would be considered material if it is likely, individually or in aggregate, to affect the economic decisions of users of the financial statements.

During the audit conducted in accordance with the Audit Commission's auditing standards, I will apply professional judgment and maintain an attitude of professional skepticism. I will also:

- Identify and assess the risks of material misstatement in the financial statements resulting from fraud or error; design and perform audit procedures to address these risks; and obtain sufficient and appropriate audit evidence to support my opinion. Because fraud may involve collusion, forgery, intentional omission, false representation, or override of internal controls, the risk of not detecting material misstatements resulting from fraud is higher than the risk of not detecting those resulting from error;

- Understand the internal control relevant to the audit to design appropriate audit procedures. However, this does not constitute an opinion on the effectiveness of the Group's internal control;

- Evaluate the appropriateness of the accounting policies adopted by the Monetary Authority and the reasonableness of the accounting estimates and related disclosures made;

- Determine whether the use of the going concern basis of accounting by the Monetary Authority is appropriate, and, based on the audit evidence obtained, determine whether there are material uncertainties related to events or conditions that may cast doubt on the Group's ability to continue as a going concern. If I conclude that there are material uncertainties, it is necessary to draw the attention of users to the relevant disclosures in the financial statements. If the relevant disclosures are insufficient, I must issue an auditor's report with a qualified opinion. My conclusions are based on the audit evidence obtained up to the date of the auditor's report. However, future events or circumstances may cause the Group to be unable to continue as a going concern;

- Evaluate the overall presentation, structure, and content of the financial statements, including disclosures, and whether the financial statements present fairly the transactions and events;

- Plan and perform the audit of the Group to obtain sufficient and appropriate audit evidence to support my opinion on the financial statements. I am responsible for directing, supervising, and reviewing the audit work performed in connection with the audit of the Group. I bear full responsibility for my audit opinion.

I will communicate with the Audit Sub-Committee of the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee regarding the scope and timing of the planned audit and major audit findings, including any significant deficiencies in internal control identified during the audit period.

I will also submit a statement to the Audit Sub-Committee of the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee confirming that I have complied with the relevant ethical requirements regarding independence, and communicate all relationships and other matters that I reasonably believe could affect my independence, as well as any preventive measures taken where applicable.

From the matters communicated with the Audit Sub-Committee of the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, I will determine which matters are most significant to the audit of the financial statements for the current period, and thus constitute key audit matters. I will describe these matters in the auditor's report, unless legal or regulatory restrictions prevent disclosure of a particular matter.
